Relations.SupportingText: In our pilot study, MDD patients had reduced brain activation, affecting emotional stimuli processing function, executive function, and cognitive control function. Childhood maltreatment might affect brain function in MDD.

This association is supported by the impact of childhood maltreatment on brain function in MDD patients.

Papers.PaperTitle: Effect of rejection sensitivity on the development of anxious-depressive attack in Japanese outpatients: The mediating roles of rumination, social anxiety, and depressive symptoms

Relations.SupportingText: We evaluated the cognitive performance of patients with CFS using standardized verbal and visual memory tests, as well as sustained attention, working memory, and episodic memory. Our results showed that patients with CFS had slower phasic alertness and impaired working, visual, and verbal episodic memory compared to controls.
Relations.Reasoning: The text provides evidence that patients with CFS have cognitive impairments, including slower reaction times and impaired memory functions. Rumination is a form of cognitive distraction that involves repetitive and negative thoughts. Given the cognitive impairments observed in patients with CFS, it is reasonable to infer that rumination, as a form of cognitive distraction, may be present in this population.
